hints.label: def-algorithmic-space-generic
hints.title: Algorithmic Space
hints.raw_directive:
1227: ### 6.1 Specification of the Algorithmic Space
1228: :::{prf:definition} Algorithmic Space
1229: :label: def-algorithmic-space-generic
1230: An **algorithmic space** is a pair $(\mathcal{Y}, d_{\mathcal{Y}})$ consisting of a real vector space $\mathcal{Y}$ and a true metric $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ on $\mathcal{Y}$.

hints.label: def-distance-positional-measures
hints.title: Distance Between Positional Measures
hints.content:
1235: :label: def-distance-positional-measures
1236: Let two walkers, $i$ and $j$, have their positions represented by the Dirac positional measures $\delta_{x_i}$ and $\delta_{x_j}$. The distance between them in the algorithmic space is the **1-Wasserstein distance ($W_1$)** between their **projected positional measures**, with $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ as the ground metric.
1237: The projected positional measure for walker $i$ is the pushforward measure $\varphi_* \delta_{x_i} = \delta_{\varphi(x_i)}$. The distance is then:
1238: $$
1239: 
1240: d(\varphi_* \delta_{x_i}, \varphi_* \delta_{x_j}) := W_1(\delta_{\varphi(x_i)}, \delta_{\varphi(x_j)})
1241: 
1242: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1233: The distance between two walkers is formally defined as the distance between the probability measures representing their positions.
1234: :::{prf:definition} Distance Between Positional Measures
1235: :label: def-distance-positional-measures
1236: Let two walkers, $i$ and $j$, have their positions represented by the Dirac positional measures $\delta_{x_i}$ and $\delta_{x_j}$. The distance between them in the algorithmic space is the **1-Wasserstein distance ($W_1$)** between their **projected positional measures**, with $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ as the ground metric.
1237: The projected positional measure for walker $i$ is the pushforward measure $\varphi_* \delta_{x_i} = \delta_{\varphi(x_i)}$. The distance is then:
1238: $$
1239: 
1240: d(\varphi_* \delta_{x_i}, \varphi_* \delta_{x_j}) := W_1(\delta_{\varphi(x_i)}, \delta_{\varphi(x_j)})
1241: 
1242: $$
1243: For Dirac measures, the Wasserstein distance simplifies to the ground metric distance between their points of support.

hints.label: def-alg-distance
hints.title: Algorithmic Distance
hints.content:
1247: :label: def-alg-distance
1248: The **algorithmic distance** $d_{\text{alg}}\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ is the distance between the projected positional measures of two walkers. In practice, this is the distance or semidistance function $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ applied to the projected points in the algorithmic space:
1249: $$
1250: 
1251: \boxed{d_{\text{alg}}(x_1, x_2) := d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_1), \varphi(x_2))}
1252: 
1253: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1245: ### 6.3 Algorithmic Distance
1246: :::{prf:definition} Algorithmic Distance
1247: :label: def-alg-distance
1248: The **algorithmic distance** $d_{\text{alg}}\colon\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$ is the distance between the projected positional measures of two walkers. In practice, this is the distance or semidistance function $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ applied to the projected points in the algorithmic space:
1249: $$
1250: 
1251: \boxed{d_{\text{alg}}(x_1, x_2) := d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_1), \varphi(x_2))}
1252: 
1253: $$
1254: This is the practical implementation of the Wasserstein distance between the walkers' projected Dirac measures and serves as the ground distance for all subsequent calculations.
